title: Resources
text:
Grad School
Thinking about grad school? Check out the slides or recording from a talk I gave about grad school at eUSR 2020.

title: Resources
text:
Job Market
On the job market? Read the September newsletter from the American Statistical Association’s Section on Statistics in Genomics and Genetics (SSGG). I contributed some reflections and tips on applying for jobs at liberal arts colleges, and there is also great advice from others on applying for other types of jobs.

title: Resources
text:
Stay Tuned…
More resources coming soon!

title: About Me
text:
Hello! Welcome to my website.
My name is Kelsey Grinde (KELL-see GRIN-dee) and I use the pronouns she/her/hers. I am a biostatistician and Assistant Professor of Statistics at Macalester College in St. Paul, Minnesota. I am originally from the Twin Cities and am happy to back as of 2019.
Before coming to Macalester, I spent five years in Seattle pursuing my PhD in Biostatistics at the University of Washington. My interest in statistics was first inspired by wonderful professors at St. Olaf College, where I pursued a BA in mathematics.
I can also thank St. Olaf for introducing me to my spouse, Zack: we met on the intramural soccer field. (Coincidentally, my parents also met playing soccer at St. Olaf.) I am a lifelong soccer player and fan, and this continues to be one of my favorite ways to spend time outside of work. In what’s left of my free time, I also enjoy trying new restaurants, breweries, and coffee shops around the Twin Cities, listening to local radio station The Current, and traveling. The picture on this page is from a February 2024 trip to Fiordland National Park in New Zealand.

title: Research
text:
My primary research interests are in the areas of biostatistics and statistical genetics. Most recently, my work has focused on developing and applying statistical methods for genetic studies in admixed populations—populations with mixed and diverse ancestry such as African Americans and Hispanics/Latinos—which have been vastly underrepresented in genetics research to date. For example, one of my recent projects developed methods and a corresponding R package (the latter of which has ongoing involved collaboration with Macalester students) for controlling for multiple testing in genome-wide admixture mapping studies.
Methodologically, I am particularly interested in addressing the statistical challenges posed by genetic data, such as their high dimensional nature, sparsity, and complicated correlation structure, as well as concerns about confounding and collider bias that can arise in these studies. In general, I strive to ensure that my applied and methodological work is grounded in a deep understanding of the context (scientific, ethical, etc.) surrounding the data with which I am working. This often involves close collaboration with experts in other disciplines and, whenever possible, undergraduate students.

title: Research
text:
Current Projects

Updating the STEAM R package, in collaboration with Macalester students Zuofu Huang (’21), Tina Chen (’25), Sydney Ohr (’26), and Katelyn McClure (’26)
Understanding the power—and limitations—of admixture mapping studies, in collaboration with Macalester student Tina Chen (’25)

Read more about our group on our GitHub page.

title: Research
text:
Publications
My most recent publication can be found in PLOS Genetics:

Grinde KE, Browning BL, Reiner AP, Thornton TA, Browning SR (2024) Adjusting for principal components can induce collider bias in genome-wide association studies. PLOS Genetics 20(12): e1011242. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1011242

You can find a full list of publications on my CV or Google Scholar.

title: Kelsey E. Grinde
text:
I am an Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics, Statistics, and Computer Science at Macalester College in St. Paul, Minnesota.
At Macalester, I teach courses across our undergraduate statistics and data science curriculum. You can find a complete list of the courses I have taught, and their corresponding course materials, on my Teaching page.
My research focuses on developing and applying statistical methods to answer questions about human health and genetics. Read more about current and past projects on my Research page.
I enjoy talking with students about research, graduate programs, and career opportunities in (bio)statistics. If you are a looking to learn more about opportunities in this field, please get in touch and/or check out the Resources page.
If you’re looking to learn more about me, otherwise, take a look at my CV or About Me page.

title: Teaching
text:
At Macalester, I teach classes ranging across all levels of our undergraduate statistics and data science curriculum, from introductory statistics to upper-level statistical theory. Materials for each of these courses are provided in the table below.
Before coming to Macalester, I was an instructor and teaching assistant for various undergraduate and graduate biostatistics courses at the University of Washington. More details about the latter are available on my CV.
